Compression of Paths

Hauke Sonnenberg

2019-03-17

Source: vignettes/compress.Rmd
compress.Rmd

See the Working with File Paths in R Scripts for an introduction on how we suggest to handle file paths in R scripts.

Define some Example File Paths

paths <- c(
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1/input/file 1.csv",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1/input/file-2.csv",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1/analysis/summary.pdf",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp 2/input/köpenick_dirty.csv",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp 2/output/koepenick_clean.csv",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Daten/file-1.csv",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Grafiken/file 1.png",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Berichte/bericht-1.doc",
  "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Berichte/bericht-2.doc"
)

Compress the Paths

kwb.pathdict:::compress_paths(paths)
#> [1] "<a1>/file 1.csv"          "<a1>/file-2.csv"         
#> [3] "<a3>/summary.pdf"         "<a5>/köpenick_dirty.csv" 
#> [5] "<a4>/koepenick_clean.csv" "<a7>/file-1.csv"         
#> [7] "<a6>/file 1.png"          "<a2>/bericht-1.doc"      
#> [9] "<a2>/bericht-2.doc"      
#> attr(,"dict")
#> attr(,"dict")$a1
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1/input"
#> 
#> attr(,"dict")$a2
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Berichte"
#> 
#> attr(,"dict")$a3
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1/analysis"
#> 
#> attr(,"dict")$a4
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp 2/output"
#> 
#> attr(,"dict")$a5
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp 2/input"
#> 
#> attr(,"dict")$a6
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Grafiken"
#> 
#> attr(,"dict")$a7
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Daten"
kwb.pathdict:::compress_paths(paths, maxdepth = 2)
#> [1] "<a1>/file 1.csv"          "<a1>/file-2.csv"         
#> [3] "<a3>/summary.pdf"         "<a5>/köpenick_dirty.csv"

#> [7] "<a6>/file 1.png"          "<a2>/bericht-1.doc"

#> 
#> attr(,"dict")$b3
#> [1] "//very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1"
kwb.pathdict:::compress_paths(paths, maxdepth = 4)
#> [1] "<a1>/file 1.csv"          "<a1>/file-2.csv"         
#> [3] "<a3>/summary.pdf"         "<a5>/köpenick_dirty.csv"

Importance of Directories

In order to find the most important folder paths in terms of frequency and length you may use the function sorted_importance():

kwb.pathdict:::sorted_importance(dirname(paths))
#> x
#>    //very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1/input 
#>                                                      106 
#>      //very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Berichte 
#>                                                      102 
#> //very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp-1/analysis 
#>                                                       56 
#>   //very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp 2/output 
#>                                                       54 
#>    //very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-1/wp 2/input 
#>                                                       53 
#>      //very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Grafiken 
#>                                                       51 
#>         //very/long/path/to/the/projects/project-2/Daten 
#>                                                       48

Compression of Folder Paths

Assume you have a folder with a long path (either due to a lot of levels or due to long folder names). This long path is repeated for each file in the folder. The package kwb.pathdict provides a compress() function that may be used to introduce short names for directory paths.

directories <- c(
  "short/path/to/directory", 
  "short/path/to/directory", 
  "short/path/to/directory", 
  "longer/path/to/another/directory", 
  "longer/path/to/another/directory"
)

short_dirs <- kwb.pathdict:::compress(directories)

as.character(short_dirs)
#> [1] "<a1>" "<a1>" "<a1>" "<a2>" "<a2>"

The function returns the lookup table (dictionary) that maps short names to long names in the attribute dict:

(dictionary <- kwb.utils::getAttribute(short_dirs, "dict"))
#> $a1
#> [1] "short/path/to/directory"
#> 
#> $a2
#> [1] "longer/path/to/another/directory"

The dictionary is sorted by the importance of the strings (paths) that have been given to compress() so that the most important paths get the highest positions in the dictionary. With importance we mean the product of the length of a string (path) and its number of occurrences.

The dictionary is required to convert the short names back to the original paths using the resolve() function of the kwb.utils package:

(long_dirs <- kwb.utils::resolve(short_dirs, dictionary))
#> [1] "short/path/to/directory"          "short/path/to/directory"         
#> [3] "short/path/to/directory"          "longer/path/to/another/directory"
#> [5] "longer/path/to/another/directory"

identical(long_dirs, directories)
#> [1] TRUE

There is another function compress_one_by_one, what does it do?

attributes(kwb.pathdict:::compress_one_by_one(paths, n = 3))
#> Splitting paths ... ok. (0.00s) 
#> Elapsed: 0.0 s
#> Splitting paths ... ok. (0.00s) 
#> Elapsed: 0.0 s
#> Splitting paths ... ok. (0.00s) 
#> Elapsed: 0.0 s
#> NULL
